exegeticalPlan.title: Exegetical Plan
exegeticalPlan.intro: An exegetical plan helps see the overall flow of what the text says.

simpleStudy.title: Simple study of the text structure
simpleStudy.note: This section explains how to compose the exegetical plan.
simpleStudy.definition: A passage plan is a structural expression of the development of its main idea. It must arise from the text, not be imposed on it.
simpleStudy.requirementsIntro: Each point of the plan should meet several requirements:
simpleStudy.req1: First, it must come from the text.
simpleStudy.req2: Second, it should reveal the main idea of the passage.
simpleStudy.req3: Third, it should be parallel with other points.
simpleStudy.req4: Fourth, it should be short, concise and precise.
simpleStudy.goal: The goal is not to build a perfect construction, but to reflect the development of the main idea of the passage.

unityOrderProgress.logicalChronological: Points should have logical and chronological connection:

principles.title: General principles for composing a sermon plan
principles.p1: Each point must support the sermon thesis.
principles.p2: Each subpoint must support the main point it belongs to.
principles.p3: Each (sub)point should consist of one assertion.
principles.p4: Each (sub)point should accomplish the goal set by the thesis.
principles.p5: Each group of points should be united by one idea.
principles.p6: Each group of points should have a parallel structure.
principles.p7: You cannot have a single subpoint: if there is 1 — there must be 2; if A — then B.
principles.p8: Each point must be expressed clearly.
principles.p9: Each point must be proven or supported from Scripture and sound logic.
principles.p10: Each point should be illustrated or explained; help listeners apply the truth in practice.

qualities.title: c) Different qualities of one subject

items.deductive: 1) Deductive: thesis/title stated at the beginning; the sermon substantiates the thesis.
items.inductive: 2) Inductive: thesis or title is formed at the end of the study.
items.narrative: 3) Narrative: from a historical narrative text derive biblical principles and commands.
items.biographical: 4) Biographical: study a biblical character’s life (stage) and draw lessons.
items.problemSolution: 5) Problem → Solution: raise a relevant problem from the text and give a biblical solution.
items.thematic: 6) Thematic: reveal an important topic using several Scripture texts.
items.motivational: 7) Motivational: goal is to move listeners to important church decisions.
items.dramatic: 8) Dramatic: preacher’s monologue to involve listeners emotionally and spiritually.
